item.title: 10 Perfect PlayStation Games Nobody Remembers
item.description:
The PlayStation brand is now almost 30 years old. That's a long time for a console to play host to video games, and unsurprisingly, there have been a lot of video games on PlayStation consoles over those three decades. There are all-time classics like Final Fantasy 7 or God of War, and underrated hits like the first Helldivers.

Then there are those games that are damn near perfect, yet they've been completely forgotten. These games aren't a bit underrated or cult classics; they've basically been erased from the public's memory. No remasters, no remakes, no sequels, and rarely even a mention in the conversation of underrated games. You may never have heard of these games, and there's a pretty good chance you didn't get around to playing them, but they're fantastic, and many of them still hold up today.

Shipwreckers!

A Pirate Ship Adventure

Platforms

PS1, PC, macOS, Nintendo Switch

Released

October 28, 1997

Developer

Psygnosis

Genre

Action Adventure

Also known as Overboard! in Europe, Shipwreckers! is a top-down action adventure game where you control a pirate ship that's helmed by Captain Blowfeet and his two crew members. You sail through five different nations — from the Carribean to the Arctic — battling other pirates and seeking treasure.

The mechanics in Shipwreckers! may be simple, but they're fine-tuned to the point that they become addictive. Ships control very well in both exploration and combat, and the variety of settings keep things interesting throughout. The game's best is definitely found in local multiplayer, which adds a pleasing chaotic element to this overlooked PS1 classic.

The Mark Of Kri

Polynesian-Inspired Action Adventure

Platforms

PlayStation 2

Released

July 30, 2002

Developer

San Diego Studio

Genre

Action Adventure

The Mark of Kri still looks fantastic, even though it is turning 24 years old in 2026. That's largely due to its art team being made up of former 2D animators, including some from Disney. This game is more than just a looker though; it's an action adventure title with a heavy focus on shockingly violent stealth.

The art is inspired by a variety of Polynesian cultures, while the world is steeped in Maori mythology. The latter received some heavy criticism from New Zealand, where some felt the game took some insensitive liberties with Maori culture. Regardless, it's a unique mythology to build a game around, and it helps make The Mark of Kri stand out in both its visuals and its narrative, while the unusual control scheme and brutal combat make the moment-to-moment gameplay some of the PS2's best.

Shadow Of Rome

Gladiator Combat With Political Intrigue

Platforms

PlayStation 2

Released

February 8, 2005

Developer

Capcom

Genre

Action Adventure

It's surprising that more people don't remember Shadow of Rome. Developed by Capcom with western audiences in mind, and likely inspired by the success of Ridley Scott's Gladiator, Shadow of Rome uses a fictional reinterpretation of the assassination of Julius Caesar as its jumping off point. From there, protagonist Agrippa is sent to the arena after his father is accused of the killing. Meanwhile, the other playable character, Octavianus, sneaks his way through Rome, looking for evidence to clear Agrippa's father's name.

Shadow of Rome has everything you could want from a Roman gladiator game. The arena combat is excellent: it's challenging, extremely bloody, and looks great. Meanwhile, Octavianus' storyline is more focused on stealth and politics as he scours the Roman elite for answers. It's a great, engaging story buoyed by excellent visuals. Maybe the strangest thing of all is that Capcom greenlit a sequel to Shadow of Rome before the game even launched, and when it floundered financially, that sequel was (somehow) repurposed into Dead Rising.

Star Wars: Starfighter

Starship Dogfights Both In Space And On Planets

Star Wars: Starfighter
Action
Systems
Released
February 21, 2001

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T
Developer(s)
LucasArts, Blitz Games, Secret Level Studios
Genre(s)
Action
Powered by

Back in the 90s and early 2000s, Star Wars games were trying all kinds of ideas. It wasn't just about Jedi and the Force; podracing, scoundreling, and flying a spaceship were all explored in video game form. One such game, riding the high of The Phantom Menace, was Star Wars: Starfighter.

What makes Starfighter stand out is that not only do you do battle in space; you'll engage in dogfights down on planets, too, flying over fields, through mountain passes, and above vast oceans. It's a brilliant way to mix up the standard space dogfighting game formula. It helps that you have full control over your ship, which makes navigating the tight confines of planet-level conflict more manageable, and as a result, making you feel like a badass starfighter pilot. To encourage additional attempts, each level has a pair of secret objectives, and completing them can unlock bonus levels. It's great stuff.

The Warriors

Back When Rockstar Worked On More Than Two Franchises

The Warriors
Action-Adventure
Beat 'Em Up
Systems
Released
October 17, 2005
ESRB
M // Blood, Intense Violence, Sexual Themes, Strong Language, Use of Drugs and Alcohol

Developer(s)
Rockstar Toronto, Rockstar Leeds
Genre(s)
Action-Adventure, Beat 'Em Up
Powered by

Rockstar was known for more than just GTA and Red Dead in the mid-2000s. They made a surprisingly good table tennis game, Bully, Midnight Club, Manhunt, and seemingly out of nowhere, an adaptation of the 1979 cult classic film The Warriors. This is a game that no one was really asking for, no one was expecting, and fans of the movie likely weren't very enthused about it. That is, until they played it.

The Warriors may be a retelling of the same story as the film it shares its name with, but the gameplay is brilliantly modern. You can play as one of nine members of the Warriors gang on each mission, from their warchief to their graffiti artist, train their skills at the gang's hideout, and then brawl it out with any of the other rival gangs from the film, dishing out simeple to complex combos, grapples, counters, and weapon attacks. The story is even expanded from the movie's, with a series of excellent flashback missions that detail how each member came to join The Warriors in the first place. Between the pedigree of the developer and the quality and depth of the product itself, it's crazy that The Warriors has been forgotten.

Majin And The Forsaken Kingdom

Before The Last Guardian, There Was...

Platforms

PlayStation 3, Xbox 360

Released

November 23, 2010

Developer

Game Republic

Genre

Action Adventure

Set in a fantasy kingdom overtaken by a mysterious darkness, Majin and the Forgotten Kingdom starts Tepeu, a thief tasked with freeing a mythical Majin and helping it regain its powers so that it can cleanse the land and return it to its once-great splendor. Developed by Game Republic, the makers of Folklore (another great but forgotten PlayStation game) and the Genji series, this is an action adventure game with puzzle elements akin to an older The Last Guardian.

Players control Tepeu exclusively, but they can issue orders to the Majin, Teotl, in combat and when solving puzzles. Teotl is incredibly strong, able to lift massive objects and plow through swaths of enemies. The creature helps protect the more vulnerable Tepeu when the going gets tough. Majin and the Forgotten Kingdom is a gorgeous game with a great story at its core; the only blemish on it is some lackluster voice acting.

Binary Domain

The Yakuza Team's Sci-Fi Shooter

Binary Domain
Third-Person Shooter
Systems
Released
February 28, 2012

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Strong Language, Suggestive Themes
Developer(s)
Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio
Genre(s)
Third-Person Shooter
Powered by

Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio are best known (and arguably only known) for the Yakuza/Like a Dragon series, but back in 2012, the developer took a stab at the third-person cover shooter genre with Binary Domain. It's a sci-fi shooter where you control Dan Marshall, a member of Rust Crew who is dispatched to Tokyo to unravel the connections behind a pair of warring robotics companies.

Much like the Yakuza series, Binary Domain has a lot more going on than just third-person shooting. There are turret levels, jetski sequences, boss battles, a mission in a futuristic cannabis farm, and more. However, also similar to Yakuza, these distractions are little more than palette cleansers for the main event: the combat, which in this case is some fantastic shooting gameplay. Blowing away robots simply never gets old, from the way parts fly off of them to the variety of weapons at your disposal. Binary Domain is goofy, action-packed, and well worth your time, and it's a shame more people don't remember it.

Tokyo Jungle

A Sci-Fi Survival Game With Playable Animals

Tokyo Jungle
Survival
Systems
Released
September 25, 2012

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen due to Suggestive Themes, Violence, Blood, Crude Humor
Developer(s)
Crispy's!
Genre(s)
Survival
Powered by

There aren't many games that let you play exclusively as an animal, but there are even fewer games that let you play as almost 50 different animals. That's the major element that sets Tokyo Jungle apart. It's a post-apocalyptic survival game set in a world where humankind is mostly extinct. In their absence, animals must once again fend for themselves, and you play as the various faunae that are reclaiming the city of Tokyo.

Subscribe to the newsletter for forgotten PlayStation gems

Want more unheralded PlayStation classics and similar deep dives? Subscribe to the newsletter to get curated explorations, thoughtful recommendations, and context that help you rediscover forgotten games and gaming history.
By subscribing, you agree to receive newsletter and marketing emails, and accept Valnet’s Terms of Use and Privacy Policy. You can unsubscribe anytime.

You begin as a single pomeranian who has run out of food and must set out to find a way to survive. You'll battle cats and eventually establish a small pack of poms. Then, you move on to the next animal. While the mechanics for each creature aren't all that complex, you also aren't playing as any of them for long (unless you want to goof around for a while), so it never starts to drag. Pomeranians are just the beginning. Soon, you'll be playing as a lion, a crocodile, a lion, a hyena, and more. There really isn't any other game like Tokyo Jungle, but there doesn't need to be. This one already perfectly accomplishes what it tries to do.

The Eye Of Judgement

One Of The Best Reasons To Own A PlayStation Eye

Platforms

PlayStation 3

Released

October 23, 2007

Developer

Japan Studio

Genre

Collectible Card Game

The PlayStation Eye was a webcam-like device for the PS3 that would translate the physical movements of players into inputs in a game, to varying degrees of success. There are a surprising number of games that incorporated some of the PS Eye's features, including PES 09, Def Jam Rapstar, and LittleBigPlanet 2, but the best game to use this peripheral by far — and also the first — was The Eye of Judgement.

You know how it is really cool in the Yu-Gi-Oh! anime when they play a card and a visible hologram of the card appears on the playing field? That's what The Eye of Judgement tries to emulate. This is a CCG where you need to collect real-world cards, build a deck, and then, while using a game-specific playing mat, pit your deck against those of your friends. There was an online option for playing against strangers, but it was pretty hit or miss. The best experience was playing in-person. Gameplay was simple enough for newcomers to have fun instantly, but deceptively complex enough to encourage veterans to keep coming back. Funny enough, of all the games on this list, The Eye of Judgement has maintained the most consistent in-person playerbase, even if the online servers were shut down ages ago.

ModNation Racers

A Kart Racer With A Deep Track Creation System

ModNation Racers
Racing
Systems
8 /10
Released
May 25, 2010
ESRB
e

Developer(s)
United Front Games
Genre(s)
Racing
Powered by

ModNation Racers is a kart racing game that, before launch, was not compared to Mario Kart so much as it was compared to LittleBigPlanet. It's a surprisingly challenging game, especially the career mode, but it makes up for it with silky-smooth controls, unique weapon pickups, and some excellent online or local competitive options that make racing against other players a fantastic experience.

However, the real draw here is the customization options. You can edit your racers to look like basically anything you can imagine, and customize the visuals on their kart as well. What players spent the most time on, though, was the track creation system. This thing is robust in the best way possible, and with the wacky, over-the-top nature of kart racers, it allows for some truly wild ideas. Best of all, you can upload and share your track creations for others to try out, and you can check out community-created tracks too, which are often the best tracks in the game.

item.title: GameStop Issues Statement on 'Infinite Money Glitch' and Puts a Stop to It
item.description:
GameStop has just issued an official statement regarding the 'Infinite Money Glitch' that was first spotted by YouTuber RJCmedia earlier this month. This 'Infinite Money Glitch' saw RJCmedia trading in a Nintendo Switch 2 and using a pre-owned promotion to earn a profit in GameStop store credit.

RJCmedia's channel dates back to May 2022, with the creator's first few videos following his attempts to earn money via DoorDash. After a year-long hiatus, RJCmedia returned to YouTube in 2023, this time focusing his content on retro gaming collections. Since 2023, RJCmedia has continued to publish gaming-related videos regularly, including quite a few that revolve around GameStop, such as hunts for GameStop pre-owned 'holy grails' and videos that see the creator using GameStop sales to expand his personal collection.

"Our Stores Are Not Designed To Function As Infinite Money Printers" — GameStop Puts Abrupt End to 'Infinite Money Glitch'

On January 17, 2026, RJCmedia posted a video with the title "I Found The GameStop Infinite Money Glitch." The first half of this 13-minute video sees RJCmedia and fellow content creator WoodmanClassics using several GameStop promotions to make the most out of their bulk trade-ins. These include GameStop's long-term promotion where GameStop Pro members can get 20% extra trade-in value when they put it towards a pre-order, and a current promotion that gives customers an extra 25% trade-in value when they use it to purchase a pre-owned item.

The second half of this video, and the part GameStop is concerned with, details the 'Infinite Money Glitch' referenced in the YouTube video's title. This section sees RJCmedia trading in a Nintendo Switch 2 and purchasing a pre-owned game to earn an extra 25% trade-in value. RJCmedia purchases the Nintendo Switch 2 for $415 and trades it in for $385 store credit. However, when the pre-owned game is scanned, the promotion kicks in and that $385 store credit becomes $445. This is $30 more than RJCmedia paid for the Nintendo Switch 2, meaning that they'd made a profit by using this GameStop promotion.

On January 20, three days after RJCmedia posted the original video, GameStop published an official statement regarding the glitch. GameStop's statement begins with a succinct summary of the 'Infinite Money Glitch' discovered by RJCmedia, and goes on to confirm that this glitch has been "patched." As GameStop's somewhat tongue-in-cheek statement puts it:

"Trade promotions have been updated to ensure customers can no longer convert basic arithmetic into an endless revenue stream, and balance has been restored...While we applaud the creativity, we gently remind everyone that our stores are not designed to function as infinite money printers."

The replies to GameStop's official statement on X are quite varied. While some speculate on how much RJCmedia made using this glitch before GameStop found out, others are calling the creator a "legend," and one even says that this is "a huge win for society." Over in the YouTube comments, other customers are sharing how much they allegedly made using this GameStop infinite money glitch, with some claiming they're now sitting on almost $1,000 of "free" store credit.

Subscribe to the newsletter for clear GameStop breakdowns

Curious how GameStop's 'infinite money' glitch unfolded and was patched? Subscribing to our newsletter provides concise, source-driven coverage and clear explanations of this incident and related gaming-retail developments to help you understand the story.
By subscribing, you agree to receive newsletter and marketing emails, and accept Valnet’s Terms of Use and Privacy Policy. You can unsubscribe anytime.

Despite only being a few weeks into 2026, GameStop has already made headlines a handful of times, not including this one. On January 9, GameStop confirmed that it was closing down almost 300 stores, seemingly without giving many of its employees any prior warning. And just a few days ago, GameStop received heat online for criticizing the first official image of Sophie Turner as Tomb Raider 's Lara Croft. GameStop's X account (the same one it used to make the statement above) reposted IGN's image of Sophie Turner, giving it a caption that read, "This is not Lara Croft." Many Tomb Raider fans came to Turner's defense, turning the tables on GameStop by posting pictures of GameStop toy shelves with captions like "This is not a gaming store."

item.title: PS Plus Subscribers Have to Say Goodbye to 9 Games in February 2026
item.description:
PlayStation Plus subscribers will be losing access to nine games in February 2026. Every month, a new batch of games is added to the Extra and Premium tiers of PlayStation Plus. That's cause for celebration for sure, but the same day that new games are added, a selection of titles are also booted off the service.

The latest update saw PS Plus Extra and Premium subscribers gain access to games like Resident Evil Village and Like a Dragon Infinite Wealth , but they also had to say goodbye to titles like Like a Dragon Gaiden: The Man Who Erased His Name and Sayonara Wild Hearts . We have no idea what new games will be added to PS Plus Extra and Premium in next month's update (presumably taking place on February 17), but we do know what games are on the chopping block in February 2026.

Come February 17, PS Plus subscribers will be losing access to Carto , Cult of the Lamb , New World: Aeternum , Rez Infinite , SaGa Frontier Remastered , Spirit of the North: Enhanced Edition , Super Neptunia RPG , The Ascent , and WWE 2K25 . Notably, New World: Aeternum has already been delisted ahead of its servers shutting down on January 31, 2027, so if you didn't already have it downloaded, you've already missed the boat on that particular game.

List of Games Leaving PS Plus in February 2026

  • Carto
  • Cult of the Lamb
  • New World: Aeternum
  • Rez Infinite
  • SaGa Frontier Remastered
  • Spirit of the North: Enhanced Edition
  • Super Neptunia RPG
  • The Ascent
  • WWE 2K25

Unfortunately, some of the games leaving PS Plus Extra and Premium in 2026 are rather notable titles. Cult of the Lamb is a dark, demented roguelike twist on something like Animal Crossing that won multiple awards and earned critical acclaim at the time of its original release in 2022. Rez Infinite is the latest version of the PS2 classic rail shooter game, complete with virtual reality support. Its departure means yet another VR title is being purged from the PS Plus lineup.

PS Plus subscribers may also be sad to see WWE 2K25 removed from the service. The latest installment in the long-running wrestling game franchise, WWE 2K25 earned mostly positive reviews, with many hailing it as one of the best entries the series has seen in years, despite the controversial Island mode. It was recently confirmed by 2K that WWE 2K25 's servers will be shut down in March of next year, so fans of the game should keep that in mind. Regardless, PS Plus Extra and Premium subscribers only have until February 17 to play the game.

The Ascent leaving PS Plus may also sting for some players. The Ascent had more mixed reviews compared to some of the other games leaving PS Plus in February 2026, but it certainly has its fans. The Ascent is one of the local co-op games on PS Plus, so it leaving the service means subscribers will have one last option in that arena.

Subscribe to our newsletter for PS Plus game changes

Keep tabs on PlayStation Plus changes—subscribe to our newsletter for concise coverage of which Extra and Premium games are added or removed. Use the newsletter to track lineup shifts and decide which titles to keep in your library.
By subscribing, you agree to receive newsletter and marketing emails, and accept Valnet’s Terms of Use and Privacy Policy. You can unsubscribe anytime.

While it's sad to see these games removed from the PS Plus lineup, the good news is that the same day they are getting the boot, new games will make their debut. The most likely day that the PS Plus Extra and Premium games for February 2026 will be announced is Wednesday, February 11, so subscribers should mark their calendars accordingly.

item.title: Roblox: Slayer Ascension Codes (January 2026)
item.description:
Slayer Ascension is an anime-based adventure simulator where you will have to travel through worlds and defend yourself from enemies that await you along the way. You can assemble a team of units to help you, but leveling up your character and companions requires a lot of Coins, Raid Tickets, Souls, and so on.

Redeeming Slayer Ascension codes is a great opportunity to significantly change your progress by receiving rewards from the developers. In this Roblox title, the rewards are especially generous and include not only a bunch of Coins, Raid Tickets, and Souls, but also potion boosters that will make you many times more effective.

Updated January 20, 2025, by Artur Novichenko: Slayer Ascension has received fresh rewards tied to the latest updates, giving you more Coins and Potions to work with as you progress. These additions are useful for powering up faster, especially if you are actively clearing content or preparing for tougher challenges. It is worth checking back regularly, as future updates often bring more rewards like these.

All Slayer Ascension Codes

Working Slayer Ascension Codes

  • Update13 - Redeem this code to get Coins and Porions. (NEW)
  • Update12 - Redeem this code to get Coins and Porions. (NEW)
  • Update11 - Redeem this code to get Coins and Porions.
  • Update10 - Redeem this code to get Coins and Porions.
  • Update9 - Redeem this code to get Coins and Porions.
  • Update8 - Redeem this code to get Coins and Porions.
  • Update7 - Redeem this code to get Coins and Porions.
  • Update6 - Redeem this code to get 50 Seals, Coins Potion, Luck Potion, and Strength Potion.
  • Update5 - Redeem this code to get 35 Seals and Common Emblem.
  • Update4 - Redeem this code to get Coins Potion, Luck Potion, and Strength Potion.
  • Update3 - Redeem this code to get Coins Potion, Luck Potion, and Strength Potion.
  • Update2 - Redeem this code to get Coins Potion, Luck Potion, and Strength Potion.
  • Update1 - Redeem this code to get 10 Raid Tickets.
  • Revamp - Redeem this code to get Coins Potion, Luck Potion, and Strength Potion.
  • SorryFans - Redeem this code to get 1,500 Coins, 150 Souls, Coins Potion, and Strength Potion.
  • Release - Redeem this code to get 500 Coins.

Expired Slayer Ascension Codes

  • Halloween - Redeem this code to get Coins and Porions.

How to Redeem Codes for Slayer Ascension

So, now that you know what rewards await you, it's time to find out how to get them in this Roblox game. In Slayer Ascension , it's quick and easy. Just follow these steps:

  • Launch Slayer Ascension .
  • Look at the left side of the screen. There will be a bunch of buttons arranged in three rows. Among them, interact with the first one in the first row, which says Shop.
  • Once you open the Shop, you will find the redemption section at the bottom of the menu. The redemption section will contain an input field and a green Claim button below it. Now, enter one of the working codes mentioned above into the input field.
  • Finally, click on the green Claim button to submit your request for rewards.

If everything is done correctly, a notification will appear on the screen with a list of rewards received.

How to Get More Slayer Ascension Codes

To get more promo codes, it is important not to wait for them to appear but to actively search for them. The best strategy is to follow the game's social media accounts, because that is where developers primarily publish codes and even hide them in posts and announcements:

  • Official Slayer Ascension Roblox group.
  • Official Slayer Ascension game page.
  • Official Slayer Ascension Discord server.
Roblox
Released
September 1, 2006

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
Teen / Diverse Content: Discretion Advised, In-Game Purchases (Includes Random Items), Users Interact
Genre(s)
Game Creation System
Platform(s)
PlayStation 4, Xbox One, PC, Android, iOS, Meta Quest 2, Meta Quest Pro
Powered by

item.title: Roblox: Weight Lifting as a Frog Codes (January 2026)
item.description:
Weight Lifting as a Frog is an extremely fun Roblox game where you can play as a frog powerlifter. This experience allows you to perform various exercises to increase your Strength and become more powerful. You will need all this power to fight other players and conquer new zones with better equipment.

Weight Lifting as a Frog also features codes that you can use to gain an advantage over other users. In this guide, we will tell you about Weight Lifting as a Frog codes and explain how to use them.

Updated January 20, 2025, by Artur Novichenko: Weight Lifting as a Frog has received several new reward drops that you can claim right now. These additions focus on boosting your Strength while also giving you a solid amount of Gems to speed up progression. If you are pushing for higher weights or faster upgrades, grabbing these rewards can make a noticeable difference. They are especially helpful for newer players trying to catch up. Keep checking back later, as more rewards like these are often added over time.

All Weight Lifting as a Frog Codes

Working Weight Lifting as a Frog Codes

  • 200KGROUP – Gives you x555 Strength and x400 Gems. (NEW)
  • WO500 – Gives you x400 Strength and x300 Gems.
  • CHRISTMAS – Gives you x1,000 Strength and x500 Gems.
  • 100KGROUP – Gives you x999 Strength and x666 Gems.
  • DUMMY – Gives you x111 Strength and x11 Gems.
  • REAL – Gives you x200 Strength and x100 Gems.
  • BILLBOARDS – Gives you x200 Strength and x100 Gems.
  • ICE – Gives you x125 Strength and x100 Gems.
  • COLD – Gives you x100 Strength and x100 Gems.
  • POWERR – Gives you x120 Strength and x50 Gems.

Expired Weight Lifting as a Frog Codes

Currently, Weight Lifting as a Frog doesn’t have any expired codes. We will update this paragraph if any of these promo codes become unavailable to you.

Strength is the main resource in this Roblox game, as it helps you grow bigger and make your frog stronger. Luckily, there are promo codes that reward you with it for free. In addition, these codes can provide you with Gems that you can use to purchase new Pets.

How to Redeem Weight Lifting as a Frog Codes

In Weight Lifting as a Frog , you need to increase your Strength to make your frog more powerful, and promo codes can help you get extra resources. Luckily, they are very easy to redeem, and you can claim all your rewards in just a few clicks. Follow these steps to redeem all available Weight Lifting as a Frog codes:

  • Launch Weight Lifting as a Frog and wait for this Roblox game to load.
  • Once you are in the game, click on the Codes button on the left side of the screen.
  • Enter the code you want to use in the menu that pops up.
  • Click on the Enter button.
  • The reward is yours.

How to Get New Weight Lifting as a Frog Codes

The developers of this amazing Roblox experience may add more codes in the future, and if they do, we will update this article. Feel free to bookmark our guide and check it occasionally for new Weight Lifting as a Frog codes. We will try to keep it updated with all the latest codes.

Roblox

September 1, 2006
